reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s multiplicative ‘value as product of factors’ model (and its independence/uniform toy assumptions). That model is a meaningful part of the case for eutopian fragility, but it is not the only major support for the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion (which also leans on historical moral catastrophe considerations and the later technical argument about bounded/unbounded value functions), so centrality is moderate. The objection moderately weakens the product-model inference (correlation and non-product aggregation could make high-value futures less rare), but it does not decisively refute it: the essay frames it as a toy/explanatory model, correlations could still leave many low-value outcomes, and other arguments remain. Most claims in the critique are correct: independence/uniformity are contestable, and a multiplicative structure does impose strong fragility/non-compensatory assumptions many theories reject; there’s only minor imprecision (e.g., calling the product structure “substitutability” is a bit off). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Correlated moral dimensions and disputed fragility assumptions undermine the multiplicative model
